snippet.textDisplay: I think you need some more structure and talking points. The knowledge is there and the personality can work well, but need to organize your thoughts and dont assume your audience understands all the scientific terminology you use. Even if you want to introduce more sophisticated concepts, organize the information in a more gradual way. This is part of the structure and talking points that needs to be prepped beforehand

snippet.textDisplay:
Here's the takeaway science in action (correct me if im wrong):
1. every object wants to be as dense as the fluid around it
2. the closer you are to the floor of any fluid, the more pressure you are under
3. for any 2 objects in the same fluid, the bigger one has higher buoyancy force
4. there's always a tug of war on any object (inside a fluid) between the buoyancy force and gravity
5. buoyancy force wins, object goes up
6. gravity wins, object goes down
snippet.textOriginal:
Here's the takeaway science in action (correct me if im wrong):
1. every object wants to be as dense as the fluid around it 
2. the closer you are to the floor of any fluid, the more pressure you are under
3. for any 2 objects in the same fluid, the bigger one has higher buoyancy force 
4. there's always a tug of war on any object (inside a fluid) between the buoyancy force and gravity
5. buoyancy force wins, object goes up 
6. gravity wins, object goes down

snippet.textDisplay: Well technically speaking you would still weigh more. Even though farts are less dense than air, it is being compressed within you. Your total mass of your body increases when more gas (more mass) is added. In this case, increase buoyant force is really so much less significant as i dont really think that the gas makes your body have more volume? thats also why it feels painful sometimes if you hold it in too long, the gasses are pushing against your large intestine wall, but is still generally being contained in the same shape (gasses are compressible)
snippet.textOriginal: Well technically speaking you would still weigh more. Even though farts are less dense than air, it is being compressed within you. Your total mass of your body increases when more gas (more mass) is added. In this case, increase buoyant force is really so much less significant as i dont really think that the gas makes your body have more volume? thats also why it feels painful sometimes if you hold it in too long, the gasses are pushing against your large intestine wall, but is still generally being contained in the same shape (gasses are compressible)

snippet.textDisplay: Played around with neutral buoyancy in the tub with our 2yo today and wondered how much the temperature of the liquid mattered.  While she didn't understand what we were doing it was still fun.  Used an aluminum can and slowly released air from it until it sank very slowly.  You can release a little air and then turn the can upside down to trap the air and test it's buoyancy.
snippet.textOriginal: Played around with neutral buoyancy in the tub with our 2yo today and wondered how much the temperature of the liquid mattered.  While she didn't understand what we were doing it was still fun.  Used an aluminum can and slowly released air from it until it sank very slowly.  You can release a little air and then turn the can upside down to trap the air and test it's buoyancy.

Also: Are you sure all possible fart gasses would have a lower density then air even if you leave pressure out of the equation?

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Mark, I had a question. We know that farts are lighter than air at STP, but how do we know the density of a gas inside of a vessel capable of reaching pressures above atmospheric? Like you brought up with the fish, they have bladders of air that can change in volume, which changes the density of the gas allowing them to affect their overall density. In a more extreme case with say a compressed helium tank: If you weigh a completely empty helium tank, and then pressurize it up with helium, wouldn't the total weight increase, but since the tank doesn't deform it stays the same volume, and thus adding a "lighter than air" gas to a vessel actually increases its density? With a human how do we know what density/pressure the fart inside the human is? It would seem like it's above atmospheric pressure, since a fart exits you when the sphincter relaxes, instead of air rushing into you when it relaxes. Thanks in advance, love the classes.
snippet.textOriginal: Hi Mark, I had a question. We know that farts are lighter than air at STP, but how do we know the density of a gas inside of a vessel capable of reaching pressures above atmospheric? Like you brought up with the fish, they have bladders of air that can change in volume, which changes the density of the gas allowing them to affect their overall density. In a more extreme case with say a compressed helium tank: If you weigh a completely empty helium tank, and then pressurize it up with helium, wouldn't the total weight increase, but since the tank doesn't deform it stays the same volume, and thus adding a "lighter than air" gas to a vessel actually increases its density? With a human how do we know what density/pressure the fart inside the human is? It would seem like it's above atmospheric pressure, since a fart exits you when the sphincter relaxes, instead of air rushing into you when it relaxes. Thanks in advance, love the classes.

snippet.textDisplay: But farts before release are under pressure in the bowels I imagine, and since PV=nRT, with nRT constant the volume would be lower (hence density higher). Are you sure the methane under pressure is still lighter than air ?
snippet.textOriginal: But farts before release are under pressure in the bowels I imagine, and since PV=nRT, with nRT constant the volume would be lower (hence density higher). Are you sure the methane under pressure is still lighter than air ?

snippet.textDisplay:
answer :
Blue light is scattered more than other colors of light because it travels as shorter, smaller waves. This is why we see a blue sky most of the time. Closer to the horizon, the sky fades to a lighter blue or white.
snippet.textOriginal:
answer :
Blue light is scattered more than other colors of light because it travels as shorter, smaller waves. This is why we see a blue sky most of the time. Closer to the horizon, the sky fades to a lighter blue or white.

snippet.textDisplay:
answer :
Blue light is scattered more than other colors of light because it travels as shorter, smaller waves. This is why we see a blue sky most of the time. Closer to the horizon, the sky fades to a lighter blue or white.

snippet.textDisplay: I would argue that although a fart has very little mass, it contributes almost nothing to your volume. A fart is pressurized gas, so the mass contributed is greater than the volume contributed, ergo, a fart is more dense than air, ergo you weigh less when you fart.
snippet.textOriginal: I would argue that although a fart has very little mass, it contributes almost nothing to your volume. A fart is pressurized gas, so the mass contributed is greater than the volume contributed, ergo, a fart is more dense than air, ergo you weigh less when you fart.

snippet.textDisplay: The sky is blue because blue light gets scattered by the tiny air molecules in the atmosphere. And blue gets scattered the most because it has a higher frequency or travels in shorter and smaller waves.
snippet.textOriginal: The sky is blue because blue light gets scattered by the tiny air molecules in the atmosphere. And blue gets scattered the most because it has a higher frequency or travels in shorter and smaller waves.

snippet.textDisplay:
well the question is: are farts really lighter than air? sure, if you fill air temperature air and a body temperature fart into a balloon each, the density of the fart will be less. But we have potentially 2 factors working against it:
1.The Pressure of the fart inside your body. when the bacteria produce the gas it has to push away the surrounding guts, im pretty sure the pressure is at least higher than after the fart. If you fart the gas rushes out of your body, while most of that force probably comes from actually pressing with your muscles i think if you just hold it open the gas would still rush out. and at the very least the fact that when you stop pushing you stop farting means that there is some pressure areas. because its not the atmousphere pressing your cheeks shut. when you fart you lose some mass and some volume in this case aka bouyancy. so the density of the fart outside of your body doesnt mean anything.
2. The normal condition density of the fart. if the air and the fart have the same temperature, which is more dense? the chemical composition varies widely between farts (at least thats what my nose tells me), but i wouldnt be surprised if the fart with its weird molecules has a higher normal density than air, reducing the difference of the density due to the difference in temperature. im kinda dissappointed that there was no information about that given in the video.
But yeah, if you stand in water there is no doubt you get lighter.
snippet.textOriginal:
well the question is: are farts really lighter than air? sure, if you fill air temperature air and a body temperature fart into a balloon each, the density of the fart will be less. But we have potentially 2 factors working against it:
 1.The Pressure of the fart inside your body. when the bacteria produce the gas it has to push away the surrounding guts, im pretty sure the pressure is at least higher than after the fart. If you fart the gas rushes out of your body, while most of that force probably comes from actually pressing with your muscles i think if you just hold it open the gas would still rush out. and at the very least the fact that -when you stop pushing- you stop farting means that there is some pressure areas. because its not the atmousphere pressing your cheeks shut. when you fart you lose some mass and some volume in this case aka bouyancy. so the density of the fart outside of your body doesnt mean anything.
2. The normal condition density of the fart. if the air and the fart have the same temperature, which is more dense? the chemical composition varies widely between farts (at least thats what my nose tells me), but i wouldnt be surprised if the fart with its weird molecules has a higher normal density than air, reducing the difference of the density due to the difference in temperature. im kinda dissappointed that there was no information about that given in the video.
But yeah, if you stand in water there is no doubt you get lighter.

snippet.textDisplay: One of my favorite density trick that my dad used to show me and his high school students is a ketchup packet in a 2 liter bottle full of water (leave a little air at the top) if you squeeze the bottle, the packet will sink, you can make it neutrally Buoyant buy squeezing and releasing carefully :) its a lot of fun and you can even make it look like a magic trick if you practice!
snippet.textOriginal: One of my favorite density trick that my dad used to show me and his high school students is a ketchup packet in a 2 liter bottle full of water (leave a little air at the top) if you squeeze the bottle, the packet will sink, you can make it neutrally Buoyant buy squeezing and releasing carefully :) its a lot of fun and you can even make it look like a magic trick if you practice!

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Mark, as we are aware of the novel coronavirus pandemic that has gripped the world. Hope you are aware of the situation in Italy and the US. Maybe people like you, with the intellectual and physical resources can devise some  solution to equip humanity against such crisis. We need more ventilators, any way on how they may be produced on a large scale even by countries that are not as advanced financially but has ample manpower and resources. Also there is a huge scarcity of protective equipment for healthcare workers in my country(India). Even doctors are forced to reuse surgical masks!!! Can you suggest any way how we can amp up production of protective gears(maybe recycle stuff) and maybe multiply ventilators. Any designs ideas(like u designed the glitter bomb out of scratch). Maybe we can implement those regionally or get each hospital its own unit to manufacture or even recycle protective gear. maybe you can rig a ventilator to cater to more than 1 person, upload an experiment like that. Dont know if these will be possible as in all probability your country too is locked down. But if you may share any ideas please do. We need the help of creative individuals as you to be technologically armed against this crisis.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the answer to this question depends on how you define “weighing less”. I would argue that it means your weight decreases. Weight is the downward force caused by gravity: mass x 9.81. Farting releases air (which has mass) and gravity hasn’t changed. Bouyancy is a separate force which opposes weight. A scale might read less because your bouyancy has decreased more than your weight, but your weight has still decreased.
snippet.textOriginal: I think the answer to this question depends on how you define “weighing less”. I would argue that it means your weight decreases. Weight is the downward force caused by gravity: mass x 9.81. Farting releases air (which has mass) and gravity hasn’t changed. Bouyancy is a separate force which opposes weight. A scale might read less because your bouyancy has decreased more than your weight, but your weight has still decreased.
